title: Rs Fighting
content:
I saw a Flash animation a few weeks ago of four Rs fighting, but I can’t find it again. It also highlighted the differences among the Rs. The Rs were Futura, Helvetica, Arial and another sans serif. Does anyone know where it is?

 [‹ Danno the Manno a Birthday Paisanno!](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39737 "Go to previous forum topic") [Here Comes 2008 ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40449 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Thomas Levine

comments.content:
Hi Thomas, so it’s not his one? [Helvetica fighting Arial](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.engagestudio.com/helvetica/) I think I know which one you’re talking about; I found [this in an article](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.mediabistro.com/unbeige/on/ellen_lupton_my_shirts_coming_unbuttoned_26001.asp) about [Ellen Lupton](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Ellen%252BLupton): a film made by her son Jay Miller, called “Rated R.” It’s “about how to recognize fonts by the letter R.”
Fonts are: Interstate, Helvetica, Arial, and Futura, “four of the world’s most fearsome fonts,” battling to the death.
Now it’s just a fight between all the letter R’s. We can’t really explain any more than that, but it’s exactly what it sounds like. R on R R-hating. Alas, I don’t know if this film is online. F

Go to [http://www.thinkingwithtype.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.thinkingwithtype.com/ "http://www.thinkingwithtype.com/") and click on the “CRIMES AGAINST TYPOGRAPHY” section... The movie you are looking for is called “Rated R.”

Oh yeah, [there it is](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.papress.com/thinkingwithtype/resources/crimes_RatedR.htm)! To hell with frames, [Google doesn’t like them either](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.google.com/search?&q=site:http://www.thinkingwithtype.com/+%22rated+r%22).

I had been looking there, but I couldn’t find it because there was no link to “Rated R” on [this page](http://web.archive.org/web/20081012142928/http:/www.papress.com/thinkingwithtype/resources/crimes_scale.htm)—only on the other type crime pages. I’ve emailed Ellen Lupton about this.
